entry.title: Re: Create GOS attachment from xstring document
entry.content:
Hi Missschaaa,

Add the OBJECT_HEADER parameter in Function Module , it will work

* Add the OBJECT_HEADER parameter in Function Module , it will work


t_objhead = VALUE #(

  ( line = |&SO_FILENAME={ lv_file_name }| )

  ( line = |&SO_DESCRIPTION={ lv_obj_descr }| )

  ( line = |&SO_FORMAT=BIN| )       "Important

  ( line = |&SO_FILEEXT=png| ) "png

  ( line = |&SO_OBJLEN={ lv_doc_size }| )

).



CALL FUNCTION 'SO_DOCUMENT_INSERT_API1'

    EXPORTING

      folder_id                            =  ls_fol_id

      document_data              =   ls_doc_data

      document_type              =   'PNG'

*      document_type              =  'jpg'

    IMPORTING

      document_info              =  ls_doc_info

    TABLES

      contents_hex                 =  lt_solix

      OBJECT_HEADER              = lt_objhead

    EXCEPTIONS

      folder_not_exist           = 1

      document_type_not_exist    = 2

      operation_no_authorization = 3

      parameter_error            = 4

      x_error                    = 5

      enqueue_error              = 6

      OTHERS                     = 7.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR ls_doc_info-doc_id IS INITIAL.

  MESSAGE 'Failed to insert attachment' TYPE 'E'.

  RETURN.

ENDIF.

entry.title: MRP-RUN : STR ( stock transfer requisition) cansidred as depend Requirement befor approval
entry.content:
Hi,

I am facing an issue.

In our current project, the MRP strategy is based on special procurement. MRP generates a Stock Transfer Request (STR).

Manufacturing plant (1003):
When MRP runs, it generates a planned order. After that, we manually convert the planned order into a Purchase Requisition (Stock Transfer Request to the distribution plant, i.e., the supplying plant) using MD15.
These STRs are subject to a release strategy.

Distribution plant (1008):
MRP generates a Purchase Requisition based on the depend requirement generated from the manufacturing plant (1003) as an STR (Stock Transfer Request).

Requirement:
The dependent requirement in the distribution plant should be considered only for the Stock Transfer Requisition has been approved.

Current situation:
The system considers the planned order generated in plant 1003 as a dependent requirement in the distribution plant.

same for the STR NOT APPROVED 

Question:
How can we configure or handle this scenario in the system to ensure that only approved STRs are considered as depend requirement in the MD 04 of the distribution plant

entry.title: Re: Implementing SAP BTP Secure Login Service for SAP GUI - enabling SSO and MFA with corporate IdP
entry.content:
Hi @MatthiasL ,

Thanks a lot for the detailed feedback and for taking the time to try this configuration out - much appreciated.

Regarding the issue where everything looks correct (SNC + CCL parameters, cryptolib) but it still doesn‚Äôt work: from experience, when it works on one system but not reproducibly on others, the root cause is often partner name resolution. In particular, mismatches between the SNC name expected by the ABAP system and what the registry side actually presents (for example due to hostname vs FQDN differences, case sensitivity, or changes in the secure login client configuration) can cause exactly this kind of behaviour.

On the parameter naming: the correct one to use is
ccl/snc/server_partner_name_mapping_for_SLC_only
OR
ccl/snc/server_partner_name_mapping_SLC
as per the SAP note 2338952.

And thanks for the heads-up on the table formatting issue as well ‚Äî you‚Äôre absolutely right about the hidden scroll bar. I wish I would fix the readability issue as well but I lost the access to my previous community user account. I would rather publish new blog including all the changes.

Thanks again for the feedback!

entry.title: Datasphere (DSP) and SAC data and metadata versioning / backup and restore
entry.content:
Background:

Contrary to BW f.e. where full Versioning of all objects is available. Data backup directly of requests on the file-system/logical path (not SARA, but also SARA can be used). DSP and SAC have no such out-of-the-box solutions (except a handful of DSP objects). 

SAC: offers no Versioning nor Data protection 

DSP: Versioning exists for: Tables (including Remote), Views, Models, Task Chains, DACs, Replication Flows, Transformation Flows. Restore is possible only for: Tables (local only, not remote), Views, and Models. What is not versioned at all: Data Flows.

 

What exists is: Full DB backups (DB-Snapshots with RedoLogs) - Platform Backup: 

SAP: 

  • DSP and SAC Tenants: SAP creates a daily backup with 15-minute intervals for RedoLogs, but this is for disaster recovery and is not available to customers. These backups are retained for 14 days.
  • SAP HANA Cloud offers Back/Restore of the entire DB (daily plus 15-minutes RedoLogs) for 1-215 days.

3rd party (DB-snapshots):

  • Data Lakehouse (Databricks) - Connect Databricks and integrate the data into the Amazon S3 layer. Use Amazon BackUp feature, but full DB. 
  • Google's Data Cloud - Same as Databricks, but data will be in stored on Google servers instead of Amazon S3.

 

Solution/steps:

SAP Suggests pushing the data to a separate tenant - requires more admin overhead and added costs for the 'backup' tenant or creating content packages with data. 

 

Alternatives for Data backup:

#1 Push data via Replication Flow into a separated DB (create a connection to own DB / costs compared to S3, Google, separated DSP tenant are negligible). Replication Flow can export data (this is the PI/EAI/EDI functionality of DSP), Replication flows may require additional costs, but backups can be run during off-peak hours.

#2 Pull data via OData to separate DB (f.e. Azure Data Factory - create Linked Service, Create Connection, where you specify the DSP Space.View/Table, create Dataset and 'SINK' the data - suggestion is to drop and recreate the table to avoid errors when the DSP view/table structure changes)

#3 Store data in local tables - These tables would be in a separate space. Tables need to be set to disk (not in-memory), as you do not want the memory footprint to be expanded unnecessary. Least efficient alternative. 

SAC Planning data can be pushed to DSP via CDI connection (if Native is used) and then backed-up. In case of Seamless planning, the data is already in DSP stored. SAC Actuals data are expected to be acquired from DSP in our case. 

 

Alternatives for Metadata backup:

DSP and SAC via transport files -> Via CLI an automated script can be created (as of now there is no automated export job available). 

DSP offers versioning for: Tables (including Remote), Views, Models, Task Chains, DACs, Replication Flows, Transformation Flows. What is not versioned at all: Data Flows. 

 

Restore: 

SAC -> transport files. Just re-deploy into your DEV tenant and thus 'restore' the f.e. Story in the version you need. Helps a lot as complex stories with complex Java-Scripting tent to get corrupt - f.e. lose the model information. 

DSP -> Restore is possible only for: Tables (local only, not remote), Views, and Models. Everything else is only transport files. 

're-transport' is also possible from TST or PROD tenants back to DEV tenant of course.

 

References

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/0c3780ad05fd417fa27b98418535debd/ae2b2b7117c84b0aab670ddd2f...

https://help.sap.com/docs/hana-cloud/sap-hana-cloud-administration-guide/backup-and-recovery

https://me.sap.com/notes/3491324

https://me.sap.com/notes/3574161

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/43509d67b8b84e66a30851e832f66911/586699519c83489bb778878236...

 

Main blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/bw-vs-datasphere-dsp-amp-sac/ba-p/1428...

entry.title: Re: SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
@BinWang thanks for the offer.  But we got it sorted out.

The documentation above has some errors and is not complete.

1. The way via "Manage Destination Certificates" on BTP doesn't work, because you cannot import the CSR from STRUST

2. We needed to add the ECS proxy to the service (don't forget the allow-list SR). 

3. Step 6a is misleading. It says "

  1. Target System Settings: In the Host field, enter https://proxy.<your region>.hub.j4a.services.sap. As Protocol, select HTTPS." --> it's import to NOT have the HTTPS:// infront...as shown  correctly  in your screenshots

4. Create a separate PSE in STRUST. The cert needs to be created by ECS and signed by SAP CA. Should look like this:

The certificate list in the PSE must include:

CN=DigiCert Global Root G2, OU=www.digicert.com, O=DigiCert Inc, C=US
CN=DigiCert Global G2 TLS RSA SHA256 2020 CA1, O=DigiCert Inc, C=US
CN=DigiCert TLS RSA4096 Root G5, O="DigiCert, Inc.", C=US
CN=ISRG Root X1, O=Internet Security Research Group, C=US
CN=SAP Global Root CA, O=SAP AG, L=Walldorf, C=DE

Cheers,

Mark

entry.title: Re: Emarsys Api: How to retrieve all outbound emails sent...
entry.content:
Hi,

One option could be to use Webhook nodes within Automation Programs.
In each Automation Program where emails are sent, you can add a Webhook node right after the ‚ÄúSend Email‚Äù step. When the contact reaches that node, Emarsys calls your endpoint (for example, SAP CPI or an API), and from there you can create an ‚ÄúEmail sent‚Äù activity in the SAP Sales Cloud timeline.

This is aligned with the standard documentation on Creating Webhook Node Presets for Automation Programs: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_EMARSYS/b165581b13de40869ce7b59db65abb52/01faf5b5e33c47cba5d31037776bbdd3.html

Best Regards.

Fernando.

entry.title: Re: Launch of RISE with SAP Methodology & Experience Certification for Senior Roles
entry.content:
Exploring a New Evaluation Experience with AI

Recently, I had the opportunity to participate in an evaluation that went beyond selecting predefined options. This approach allowed me to integrate real aspects of my work‚Äîeven in presales‚Äîand assess how effectively I‚Äôve applied key concepts. It also provided clarity on areas that require reinforcement, supported by explanations and actionable suggestions.

One of the most notable features was the interaction design. The AI offered a friendly and approachable tone, supported multiple languages (I chose Spanish for the first time), and enabled follow-up questions whenever the intent of a question was unclear.

The feedback extended beyond technical accuracy. It included observations on tone, posture, and clarity, along with recommendations to simplify explanations and improve communication. This holistic perspective transforms the evaluation into a learning experience rather than a simple test.

Of course, it remains an evaluation, and even in a role-play scenario, the challenge of staying relaxed under assessment is real. However, the depth and quality of feedback make the process valuable and insightful.

entry.title: FINCS_MD_CONSUNIT118 ‚Äì ‚ÄúNo accounting source ledger is maintained for version P11‚Äù during Individual
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I‚Äôm facing the following error in SAP Group Reporting when executing Individual Line Item Validation:

Message No. FINCS_MD_CONSUNIT118
No accounting source ledger is maintained for version P11.

Diagnosis:
You haven‚Äôt defined an accounting source ledger in the Define Versions configuration activity.

The issue is confusing because:

  • Version P11 is a planning version and is an extension of version P01

  • In Define Versions, version P11 already has a source ledger assigned

  • The source ledger is consistent with the data stored in ACDOCP

  • Version P01 works correctly, and P11 is derived from it

  • The error occurs only during the execution of Individual Line Item Validation

 

My understanding is that plan versions should retrieve data from ACDOCP (planning) and not from an operational accounting ledger like 0L, so it is unclear why the system still complains about a missing accounting source ledger for P11.

Version P11 is not sourcing data from an accounting ledger.
The plan data is retracted from SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC Planning) into ACDOCP, and the records are correctly stored for version P11.

Has anyone experienced this situation before?

Specifically, I would like to understand:

  • Does Individual Line Item Validation require a source ledger even for plan versions?

  • Are there additional settings required for version extensions (P11 from P01)?

  • Is there any dependency between validation tasks and ledger assignment that is not obvious in configuration?

  • Could this be related to how the version is classified (Actual vs Plan) or how the extension was created?

Any guidance, SAP Notes, or configuration hints would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Re: Create Shipment VT01N tile/Business Catalogue in SAP...
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

In addition from previous comments, I could add that:

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the transportation process based on shipment documents (VT01N) from SAP R/3 is not available.

In Cloud Public, transportation can be managed in two standard ways.

Without Transportation Management, outbound deliveries are processed individually. Picking, loading, and goods issue are executed per delivery, with mass processing available via standard Fiori apps. However, there is no transportation document, no delivery consolidation at transport level, and no consolidated printout. Any grouping is performed only from a warehouse execution perspective.

For scenarios that require grouping multiple outbound deliveries, a consolidated transportation document, and alignment between transportation and warehouse execution, Basic Transportation Management (TM) is the SAP-recommended standard solution in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

With Basic TM, outbound deliveries or sales orders generate Freight Units, which represent transportation demand. Multiple Freight Units are then grouped into a Freight Order, which serves as the consolidated transportation document and is the functional Cloud equivalent of the VT01N shipment. Printing is performed at Freight Order level. Warehouse execution in EWM remains delivery-based, but deliveries are logically grouped by Freight Order, enabling better synchronization between picking, loading, and transportation. Mass PGI is supported via standard Fiori apps.

In summary, VT01N and shipment documents are not supported in Cloud Public. For transportation consolidation and document-based planning, Basic Transportation Management with Freight Units and Freight Orders is the standard and recommended approach.

Please check further details on the documents below:

3261640 - Usage of LE-TRA Route and discontinuation of Transportation features of LE-TRA in public cloud - SAP for Me

Solved: #COE KKS01 TM with using EWM in cloud? - SAP Community

Getting support on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editio... - SAP Community

3332309 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition - Restrictions for the Transportation Management processes - SAP for Me

(2622) Expert Talk: Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition - YouTube

entry.title: Re: Now Available: Certification for SAP Central Finance
entry.content:
Please note that this certification is planned to  be retired as of Dec 31st, 2025. After this date, taking this exam will no longer be possible and, in addition, staying certified will no longer be possible. This certification does not have a successor that would cover the same or similar content. Please consider the following options:
1. If you want to get certified, please choose a different certification. In the Finance area, four certifications are available, as described in this blog post. 
2. If you want to get certified for Central Finance, this will not be possible after Dec 31st, 2025.
3. If you want to stay certified on Central Finance, this will not be possible after Dec 31st, 2025. Your certification badge is valid for one year. If you refresh it at the end of December 2025, it will be valid until end of December 2026. Then it will expire.
4. There is not "stay certified" path that could move your Central Finance certification badge to a different certification badge. If you want to avoid losing your certification degree as such, you need to pass an exam on a different certification. 
5. If you want to learn about Central Finance, please note that a business process overview course for self-paced learning is available on learning.sap.com. This is the direct link: https://learning.sap.com/courses/discovering-the-value-of-sap-s-4hana-central-finance.
6. A training that covers the implementation of Central Finance is not planned to be available after Dec 31st, 2025.

entry.title: 4 Important enhancements related to Object type in SAP PM
entry.content:
Here are the top four important enhancements related to object type in SAP PM:

  1. Default value of authorization group: The object type can be proposed for motors, pumps, compressors, electrical distribution lines, transmission lines, assembly lines, etc. Now for each of the object types there can be a default value of authorization group. We can maintain those values in a Z table. If any new object type is introduced, a default value can be added. The user can add the respective value of the authorization group later on.
  2. Default value of Planner group: Planner groups generally work for a specific department or specific type of machine. In such a situation we can determine a specific planner group based on object type. This can be done by enhancing and maintaining the planner group and object type in the Z table.
  3. Determine the catalog profile based on the type of object type: The catalog profile is very important for adding technical findings in the form of codes in a notification. The catalog profile should be specific to the technical object or technical object type. So, you can maintain a catalog profile and object type in a Z table and determine the catalog profile automatically at the time of creating a technical object. At the time of creating a notification, the catalog profile is determined automatically as a part of the standard SAP feature.
  4. Determine the class and assign it to the equipment: You can determine the class automatically with respect to object type. For example, for object type "electrical pole," you can do an enhancement to determine its respective class automatically. You need to maintain the class and object type in a z table. It helps to assign the correct class to the technical object.

 

You can use user exit IEQM0003 for the check at the time of saving the equipment.

You can use the BAPI => BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE to assign the class as per the object type in a equipment.

Regards,

Vaibhav Mishra

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì ‚ÄúSmall WM‚Äù: scope...
entry.content: Hi Simon, Let me try to answer from my understanding of your question. 1. The stock can be managed on the storage location level (IM managed). To use the corresponding functionalities, e.g. stock posting, physical inventory, stock overview... there is no additional scope items need to be added in CBC (actually they are part of the enterprise management bundle). 2. The stock can be managed on the bin level (WM managed). To use the corresponding functionalities, e.g. inbound processing, outbound processing, replenishment.. additional scope items need to be activated. The scope items are like 3BR, 3BS etc. You can find the details in Process Navigator - SAP for Me -> Supply Chain -> Warehousing (there are also scope items for decentral option listed). To enable the WM managed features, a warehouse number needs to be created in the CBC org and mapped to the storage location (currently only for type "Warehouse"). With the coming 2602 upgrade, storage location with other types can also be mapped to the warehouse number, which enable an easy IM -> WM switch. A how to guide will be provided after the upgrade and there is no known limitation for SN managed materials. Using WM does not need additional licenses. The charge is per SCM user. Hope it helps. Best Regards, Clark

entry.title: Partial Good Receipt in tcode VL32N
entry.content:
Questions‚ÄÉ:
a. Is it correct that, in SAP standard, Goods Receipt via Inbound Delivery using T-code VL32N does not support partial GR, so that the Putaway Quantity must always be equal to the Delivery Quantity?

b. Are there any configurations (for example, related to delivery tolerances, item category, movement type, or warehouse process settings) that would allow the system to accept partial GR from an Inbound Delivery?

c. Does SAP have any best practices for handling partial Goods Receipt when using Inbound Delivery and Putaway Quantity?

Description‚ÄÉ:
For example, there is a Purchase Order with Material A for a quantity of 100 BAR.

An Inbound Delivery is created using T-code VL31N, and the Delivery Quantity is automatically populated as 100 BAR.

When attempting to post the Goods Receipt,
if we try to enter Putaway Quantity = 90 BAR, the system displays a warning/error and rejects the posting.

The system only allows posting if the Putaway Quantity equals the Delivery Quantity (i.e., 100 BAR).

Best regards,
Ester Wang

entry.title: Part 1: Governance in Developer Hub: Empowering Administrators with Control and Flexibility
entry.content:
Overview

Governance lies at the heart of every well-managed Developer Hub. It ensures that access, visibility, and subscription processes remain secure, compliant, and aligned with organizational policies.

Developer Hub offers integrated governance features that enable administrators to oversee and manage essential developer activities, such as user registration and product subscriptions.

As a Developer Hub administrator (assigned the AuthGroup.API.Admin role collection), you can configure governance levels that best fit your organization‚Äôs needs‚Äîstriking the right balance between openness and control.

Note: This three-part series will guide you through the full spectrum of governance in Developer Hub. In Part 2, we will extend these foundational concepts by setting up an external governance workflow for more advanced approval scenarios. In Part 3, we will take this a step further and demonstrate how to implement external governance using SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build Process Automation, enabling a fully integrated and automated approval experience.

Understanding Governance Levels in Developer Hub

Developer Hub‚Äôs governance framework is divided into two main areas: Access Governance and Subscription Governance.

  • Access Governance: Access governance determines who can see, register for, and access APIs within your Developer Hub.
    • Site Visibility Governance: Control how visible your Developer Hub catalog is to users. For detailed steps, see Manage Access.
    • User Registration Governance: Require administrator approval for new user registrations to ensure only authorized developers gain access. See Managing the Access Request of the Users.
    • Product Visibility Governance: Define which users can access specific API products using custom role collections. See Restricting Access to API Products Using Custom Role Attribute.
  • Subscription Governance: Subscription governance defines how API product subscriptions are managed. Administrators can choose to let external systems handle approval workflows by enabling external governance, ensuring that subscription decisions align with enterprise workflows and approval processes. See Manage Product Subscriptions.

Manage Product Subscriptions

Subscriptions are how developers gain access to API products in Developer Hub. Administrators can configure how these subscriptions are approved‚Äîeither automatically within the Developer Hub or through an external approval process‚Äîto ensure proper governance, control, and secure API access.

Managing Governance for Internal and External API Products

Governance works differently depending on whether your APIs are managed inside or outside the SAP ecosystem.

 SAP Managed Products are products that contain APIs managed within SAP Integration Suite. All APIs inside these products are created, published, and governed using SAP‚Äôs native capabilities‚Äîincluding automated or manual subscription approvals, user registration controls, and end-to-end lifecycle management.

Externally Managed Products are products that contain APIs managed outside SAP Integration Suite, even though the product itself is published through the platform. These APIs originate from external systems or services, and therefore require external governance mechanisms, to handle subscription requests and validations that cannot be governed directly within the platform.

Governance for SAP-Managed Products 

For APIs managed within SAP API Management, subscription approvals occur through Developer Hub based on the configured settings. The credentials to access these APIs are generated by SAP API Management.

Governance for Externally Managed Products

For APIs managed outside SAP:

  • The content administrator (AuthGroup.Content.Admin) can import external APIs, package them into products, and publish them in Developer Hub.
  • The product must be marked as subscribable by selecting the Allow Subscription checkbox.

Depending on your setup, you can choose between:

  • Governance Only: To track developer-product relationships.
  • Governance + Credential Distribution: To also share API credentials automatically upon approval.

Note: Developers cannot subscribe directly to these products within SAP.
External administrators can manually share API keys from their external gateways after approval.

Configuration Requirements Summary

To ensure smooth external governance:

  • Governance option set to Manage Approval Outside Developer Hub
  • Product marked as Allow Subscription (applicable only for externally managed products.)
  •  All SPI and destination configurations completed
  • External system properly integrated with Developer Hub API

Note:  You cannot remove or modify products with pending or approved subscriptions.
To apply configuration updates, bring the product into draft mode, make changes, and republish it.

 Conclusion

Developer Hub‚Äôs governance capabilities provide the flexibility and control modern enterprises need to manage their API ecosystems effectively.

Whether your organization prefers internal governance through SAP systems or external workflows via custom integrations, Developer Hub empowers administrators to tailor governance processes that align with their business policies‚Äîensuring secure, compliant, and well-managed API access across your developer community.

 

Related Topics:

Part 2: Setting Up an External Governance Workflow

Part 3 Configuring External Governance

entry.title: Part 2: Setting Up an External Governance Workflow
entry.content:
Organizations that require more sophisticated approval flows can configure external governance.
This setup allows subscription requests raised within Developer Hub to be reviewed, approved, or rejected through an external system (such as SAP Build Process Automation, any other custom workflow, or an custom application).

Before we dive into the implementation details, it is helpful to revisit the foundations covered in the earlier parts of this series.
In Part 1, we explored the importance of governance within Developer Hub and how administrators can configure built-in governance levels to balance openness with control.

Step 1: Enable External Governance in Developer Hub

  1. Logon to Developer Hub.
  2. Navigate to Admin Center > Manage Governance Settings, click on the Subscriptions tab, and choose Edit.
  3. Now, select the option Manage Approval Outside Developer Hub and choose Save.

This redirects all future subscription requests to your external governance system for approval.

Note: Enabling this setting alone isn‚Äôt enough‚Äîseveral prerequisites must be completed for the setup to function correctly. Make sure you first complete all prerequisite steps and only then update the governance settings.

Step 2: Implement the Service Provider Interface (SPI)

The customer subaccount administrator must implement the Service Provider Interface (SPI), which handles the redirection of subscription requests to your external system.
This could be a workflow, backend service, or UI application that processes approvals.

SPI specifications, including interface details and parameters, are available on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

 Recommendation

Use SAP Integration Suite API Management for implementing the Service Provider Interface (SPI), and SAP Build Process Automation for designing your external approval workflow. For step-by- step instruction, see Part 3: Implementing External Governance Using SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build Process Automation (add blog link).

Step 3: Create a Destination in SAP BTP Cockpit

Once the SPI is in place, create a destination in your SAP BTP subaccount that points to the SPI endpoint.
This destination should include:

  • The SPI service URL
  • Authentication credentials (e.g., OAuth2, Basic Auth)

This setup ensures Developer Hub can securely send subscription requests to your external system.

  1. In your web browser, log on to SAP BTP Cockpit and navigate to your source subaccount.
  2. Choose the Connectivity > Destinations tab in the left-hand pane.
  3. Choose Create and in the Create New Destination popup, select From Scratch to create a new destination manually.
  4. In Destination Details section, fill in all the required details according to the descriptions provided in the table and choose Create.

Note: Use the credentials provided by the customer sub-account administrator. Supported authentication methods include OAuth 2.0, Client Certificate, and Basic authentication.

Fields

Details

Name

Enter DeveloperHub_Governance_SPI as the destination name.

Type

Enter HTTP as the supported type.

Description

Enter a brief description stating the purpose of creating a new destination in the Description field.

URL

Enter the external governance application URL.

Since, in this use case, you are using the API proxy as the SPI implementation in SAP Build, enter the API proxy connectivity link in the Destination URL field and provide the corresponding authentication details.

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

Select the authentication type depending on your requirement.

    • Basic: User provides a simple username and password based authentication.
    • Client Certificate: The user provides the Key Store Source, Key Store Location, and Key Store Password. The server verifies the certificate to grant access.
    • OAuth2ClientCredentials: Used when third-party services need to access resources without sharing the user‚Äôs password. A backend service authenticating with a resource server to access an API using Client ID, Client Secret, and Token Service URL. The token URL should correspond to the customer governance application when OAuth2 is being used.

           You can also do a Check Connection to verify whether you've added the destination correctly.

Step 5: Update Developer Hub with Governance Decisions

After the external administrator approves or rejects a subscription request, that decision must be communicated back to Developer Hub.

The external governance system does this by calling the API Developer Hub - External Governance (CF) published on SAP Business Accelerator Hub, using credentials tied to the AuthGroup.External.Reviewer role collection.

Once the decision is received, Developer Hub updates the subscription status accordingly.

When Governance Takes Effect

Once all prerequisites are fulfilled and Manage Approval Outside Developer Hub is enabled:

  • New subscription requests are automatically routed to the external approval system.
  • Approvals and rejections are reflected in Developer Hub based on feedback from the external workflow.

‚ö†Ô∏èCaution:
If prerequisites aren‚Äôt configured correctly, subscription requests will fail. Always verify your setup before enabling external governance.

How the External Subscription Process Works

  1. Developer Submits a Subscription Request
    • The developer subscribes to an API product from the Developer Hub catalog.
    • The request is automatically sent to the external approval system.
  2. External Administrator Reviews the Request
    • The external admin (using a workflow, e.g., SAP Build Process Automation) reviews and approves or rejects the request.
    • They can view API details in Developer Hub or via APIs on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  3. Developer Receives the Decision
  • If approved, the developer receives a confirmation email containing a link to the application with the subscribed product.
    • If rejected, they receive a rejection email, and the pending subscription is deleted.
    • Developers can monitor request status under My Workspace ‚Üí Subscriptions ‚Üí Pending Approval.

Configuration Requirements Summary

To ensure smooth external governance:

  • Set the governance option to Manage Approval Outside Developer Hub
  • Select the Allow Subscription option for the product.
  •  Complete all the Service Provider Interface (SPI) and destination configurations
  • Integrate the external system properly using the Developer Hub API

Note: Ô∏è You cannot remove or modify products with pending or approved subscriptions.
To apply configuration updates, bring the product into draft mode, make changes, and republish it.

Conclusion

Developer Hub‚Äôs governance capabilities provide the flexibility and control modern enterprises need to manage their API ecosystems effectively.

Whether your organization prefers internal governance through SAP systems or external workflows via custom integrations, Developer Hub empowers administrators to tailor governance processes that align with their business policies‚Äîensuring secure, compliant, and well-managed API access across your developer community.

entry.title: Part 3: Implementing External Governance in Developer Hub Using SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
entry.content:
In Part 1, we explored the importance of governance within Developer Hub and how administrators can configure built-in governance levels to balance openness with control.
In Part 2, we walked through how to set up an external governance workflow, enabling subscription requests to be processed through systems such as SAP Build Process Automation.

Building on these foundations, Part 3 focuses on how to implement the Service Provider Interface (SPI) using SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì API Management and how to design and manage your approval workflow with SAP Build Process Automation. This combined approach ensures a streamlined, standardized, and well-governed integration between Developer Hub subscription flows and your organization‚Äôs external approval mechanisms.

Before we dive into the implementation details, it is helpful to revisit the foundations covered in the earlier parts of this series.

Recommended Workflow:

  1. Set up the External Workflow in SAP Build

Leverage SAP Build Process Automation to design the external governance workflow. For more information on SAP Build Process Automation, see SAP Process Automation | SAP Learning.

Sample workflow to review the applications

On click of approve/reject call the Developer Hub API to inform about the decision. You can find the API details here: Developer Hub - External Governance (CF) -Governance Decision

Sample workflow to invalidate the credentials when they were shared with Developer Hub

On click of Submit the credentials can be deleted in Developer Hub by calling the API: Developer Hub - External Governance (CF) - Deletion Confirmation

Note: If you don‚Äôt have any externally managed API products, you can skip this step.

Obtain Credentials from Workflow

Create a service instance and a service key of SAP Build Process Automation Service in SAP BTP Cockpit to obtain the credentials. For more information, see Create a Service Instance and Create a Service Key for the SAP Build Process Automation Instance | SAP Help Portal.

1. Create the API proxy that acts as your SPI implementation for SAP Build    

Prerequisite:

  • Create an API provider

a). Log on to the SAP Integration Suite.
b). Navigate to the API Configuration Page.
From the side navigation pane, choose Configure ‚Üí APIs.

c). Create a New API Proxy.
Click Create to start defining your API proxy.

  • Discover the policy template

Navigate to the Discover tab and search for the SAP API Management Governance <Link> package. Open the package and go to Artifacts. Select the template Developer Hub Governance with SAP Build Process Automation and, under Actions, choose Copy.

Steps to create an API 

  1. Log on to the SAP Integration Suite.
    Access your Integration Suite environment with administrator privileges.
  2. Navigate to the API Configuration Page.
    From the side navigation pane, choose Configure ‚Üí APIs.
  3. Click Create to start defining your API proxy.

4. Select the Provider method and fill in the required details.

From the dropdown, choose the API Provider you created for SAP Build Process Automation in the prerequisite steps. Then enter the API Name, Title, and API Base Path.

Note: In the URL field, enter: /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances.

Fields such as API State and Host Alias will populate automatically. Set the Service Type to REST.

 

5. Review your configurations and choose Create.

. Now, go to the Policies tab, click on Policy Template and choose Import. 

                  To call the SAP Build workflow, import this policy template and update the following script:

                   Script Name: setVariables

jsgovernanceWorkflowDefinitionId: The workflow ID for the governance approval/rejection process.

keyInvalidationWorkflowDefinitionId: The workflow ID for the key invalidation request.

keyInvalidationResponse:

Set to 200 if you want Developer Hub to immediately proceed with application deletion once the workflow request is created.

Set to 202 if you want Developer Hub to wait for confirmation before deleting the application.

In the top-right corner of the API details page, click the ‚ãØ (More options) button. From the dropdown menu, select Deploy.

2.  Add the API Proxy URL to the Destination in SAP BTP Cockpit

After implementing the Service Provider Interface (SPI), the customer subaccount administrator creates a destination in their SAP BTP subaccount pointing to the SPI endpoint.

  1. In your web browser, log on to SAP BTP Cockpit and navigate to your source subaccount.
  2. Choose the Connectivity > Destinations tab in the left-hand pane.
  3. Choose Create and in the Create New Destination popup, select From Scratch to create a new destination manually.
  4. In Destination Details section, fill in all the required details according to the descriptions provided in the table and choose Create.

Note: Use the credentials provided by the customer sub-account administrator. Supported authentication methods include OAuth 2.0, Client Certificate, and Basic authentication.

Fields

Details

Name

Enter DeveloperHub_Governance_SPI as the destination name.

Type

Enter HTTP as the supported type.

Description

Enter a brief description stating the purpose of creating a new destination in the Description field.

URL

Enter the external governance application URL.

Since, in this use case, you are using the API proxy as the SPI implementation in SAP Build, enter the API proxy connectivity link in the Destination URL field and provide the corresponding authentication details.

Proxy Type

Internet

Authentication

Choose OAuth2ClientCredentials.

Fetch the Client ID, Client Secret, and Token Service URL from the workflow credentials. Refer to the ‚ÄúObtain Credentials from Workflow‚Äù section for details. The token URL should correspond to the customer governance application when OAuth2 is being used.

You can also do a Check Connection to verify whether you've added the destination correctly.

3. Enable External Governance in Developer Hub

  1. Logon to Developer Hub.
  2. Navigate to Admin Center > Manage Governance Settings, click on the Subscriptions tab, and choose Edit.
  3. Now, select the option Manage Approval Outside Developer Hub and choose Save.

                This redirects all future subscription requests to your external governance system for approval.

entry.title: ALV vs ALV IDA in SAP ABAP: Simple Explanation, Differences & Examples
entry.content:
Introduction

ABAP developers have been using ALV (ABAP List Viewer) for decades to display tabular data in SAP GUI applications. With the introduction of SAP HANA and Fiori-based development, SAP delivered a new, optimized framework called ALV with IDA (Integrated Data Access).
Although both approaches serve the purpose of displaying data, they work very differently under the hood and are suitable for different use cases.

In this blog, I will explain the key differences between traditional ALV and ALV with IDA, how they behave on SAP HANA, and when you should choose one over the other.

SAP offers two main technologies to display tabular data in ABAP:

  1. Classic ALV (REUSE_ALV, CL_GUI_ALV_GRID, CL_SALV_TABLE)

  2. ALV with IDA (CL_SALV_GUI_TABLE_IDA, SAP HANA‚Äìoptimized ALV)

Although both display lists/grids, the internal architecture and performance are completely different.
IDA ALV is specifically designed for SAP HANA systems, while Classic ALV works on any system.

Simple Comparison: Classic ALV vs ALV with IDA

  Topic                                                       Classic ALV                                                            ALV with IDA
Where data comes fromFirst loads everything into an internal tableReads directly from the database (no internal table)
SpeedSlow when data is largeVery fast, made for HANA
Big data handlingCan crash or dumpHandles millions of rows easily
Memory usageUses a lot of memoryUses very little memory
Filtering & SortingDone in ABAP (slower)Done in HANA (super fast)
CustomizationMany options (buttons, colors, events)Very few options (mostly read-only)
Editable?YesNo
Events (double-click, hotspot)Many availableVery limited
System supportWorks on any SAP systemWorks only on SAP HANA / S/4HANA
Coding effortMore coding neededVery simple (few lines only)
Best forInteractive, colorful, editable ALVsFast display of very large tables
Not good forHuge datasetsCustom UI features

Example for ALV :-

REPORT ZVA_ALV_IDA.
select * from ZVA_HDR_SERVICE into table (lt_tab) up to 5 rows .
data : lv_alv type ref to cl_salv_table.
cl_salv_table=>factory(
  IMPORTING
    r_salv_table   =  lv_alv
  CHANGING
    t_table        = lt_tab
).
lv_alv->display( ).

Output : 

 

Example for ALV with IDA :-

REPORT ZVA_ALV_IDA.
DATA(lo_ida) = cl_salv_gui_table_ida=>create( 'ZVA_HDR_SERVICE' ).
lo_ida->set_maximum_number_of_rows( 5 ).
lo_ida->fullscreen( )->display( ).

Output:

Conclusion

Classic ALV

  • Best for customized, interactive, editable applications

  • Works everywhere (ECC + S/4HANA)

ALV with IDA

  • Best for high-performance, HANA-optimized, large-volume reports

  • Minimal coding, maximum performance

  • Read-only analytical UI

 

ABAP Development ,

SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database

entry.title: How to Merge Two Separate Smart Forms into a Single PDF in SAP
entry.content:
1. I received a requirement to merge two Smart Forms into a single output, even though they are not part of the same form. In other words, they are two separate Smart Forms, but the final printout should combine them for better user understanding.

  2. First, I created the Smart Forms in transaction SMARTFORMS as usual. I designed each form, placed all the required elements, and completed the layout according to the specifications.

  3. After finishing both Smart Forms, I wrote the logic in the corresponding program. In the program (using the appropriate transaction) T-Code SE38, I called each Smart Form by referencing its generated function module, as shown below.

* Data Declarations.
DATA: lv_fm_dpr     TYPE rs38l_fnam,
      lv_fm_inv     TYPE rs38l_fnam,
      lv_otf1       TYPE ssfcrescl,
      lv_otf2       TYPE ssfcrescl,
      lt_otf1       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF itcoo,
      lt_otf2       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF itcoo,
      lt_TLINE      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tline,
      lv_pdf_xstr1  TYPE xstring,
      lv_pdf_xstr2  TYPE xstring,
      lv_len        TYPE i,
      lt_data       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF raw255,
      lv_file       TYPE string,
      lv_path       TYPE string,
      lv_file_name  TYPE string,
      lv_merged_xstr TYPE xstring,
      lv_rc         TYPE i.

* Data Declarations.
DATA: ls_ctrlop TYPE ssfctrlop,
      ls_compop TYPE ssfcompop.

ls_ctrlop-no_dialog = abap_true.
ls_ctrlop-getotf    = abap_true.

* Get Function Module Names of SmartForms for form 1.
CALL FUNCTION 'SSF_FUNCTION_MODULE_NAME'
  EXPORTING
    formname = 'ZTEST_SMF'
  IMPORTING
    fm_name  = lv_fm_dpr.
* Get Function Module Names of SmartForms for form 2.
CALL FUNCTION 'SSF_FUNCTION_MODULE_NAME'
  EXPORTING
    formname = 'ZSF_TEST2'
  IMPORTING
    fm_name  = lv_fm_inv.

* Call SmartForm 1 and capture OTF (Output text format )
CALL FUNCTION lv_fm_dpr
  EXPORTING
    control_parameters = ls_ctrlop
    output_options     = ls_compop
  IMPORTING
    job_output_info    = lv_otf1.

lt_otf1[] = lv_otf1-otfdata.

* Convert to PDF (XSTRING)
CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERT_OTF'
  EXPORTING
    format       = 'PDF'
  IMPORTING
    bin_file     = lv_pdf_xstr1
  TABLES
    otf          = lt_otf1
    lines        = lt_TLINE
  EXCEPTIONS
    OTHERS       = 1.

* Call SmartForm 2 and capture OTF
CALL FUNCTION lv_fm_inv
  EXPORTING
    control_parameters = ls_ctrlop
    output_options     = ls_compop
  IMPORTING
    job_output_info    = lv_otf2.

lt_otf2[] = lv_otf2-otfdata.

* Convert to PDF (XSTRING)
CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERT_OTF'
  EXPORTING
    format       = 'PDF'
  IMPORTING
    bin_file     = lv_pdf_xstr2
  TABLES
    otf          = lt_otf2
    lines        = lt_TLINE
  EXCEPTIONS
    OTHERS       = 1.

* Merge the two XSTRING PDFs
DATA(lo_merger) = NEW cl_rspo_pdf_merge( ).
lo_merger->add_document( lv_pdf_xstr1 ).
lo_merger->add_document( lv_pdf_xstr2 ).

* merging 2 documents into one
lo_merger->merge_documents(
  IMPORTING
    merged_document = lv_merged_xstr
    rc              = lv_rc ).

IF lv_rc <> 0.
  MESSAGE 'PDF merge failed. Please check input documents.' TYPE 'E'.
ENDIF.

* Converting XSTRING to binary table
CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY'
  EXPORTING
    buffer        = lv_merged_xstr
  IMPORTING
    output_length = lv_len
  TABLES
    binary_tab    = lt_data.


CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>file_save_dialog
  EXPORTING
    window_title         = 'Save Combined PDF'
    default_file_name    = 'Combined_SmartForms.pdf'
    default_extension    = 'pdf'
  CHANGING
    filename             = lv_file_name
    path                 = lv_path
    fullpath             = lv_file
  EXCEPTIONS
    OTHERS               = 1.

IF lv_file IS INITIAL.
  MESSAGE 'File path not selected' TYPE 'I'.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Download Merged PDF to Frontend
CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download
  EXPORTING
    bin_filesize = lv_len
    filename     = lv_file
    filetype     = 'BIN'
  CHANGING
    data_tab     = lt_data
  EXCEPTIONS
    OTHERS       = 1.

* Open PDF after saving
CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>execute
  EXPORTING
    document    = lv_file
    synchronous = 'X'
  EXCEPTIONS
    OTHERS      = 1.

After the code is executed, the system will prompt you to enter the name or path of your local device, as shown below. This allows the application to determine where the generated PDF should be saved.

Next, the system will once again prompt you to click on Print Preview for the second PDF.
After that, you will be required to select the destination path where the merged PDF should be downloaded and saved on your local device.

the final output will be generated in PDF format, where both Smart Forms‚Äîoriginally created as two separate documents‚Äîwill be successfully combined into a single, unified PDF file.

CONCLUSION:
Upon executing the above code, you must specify the desired local system path where the output should be saved. Once the path is provided, the system will generate and download a single PDF file to your local machine. This PDF will contain both Smart Forms seamlessly merged into one consolidated document.

Thank You...

ABAP Connectivity 

ABAP Extensibility 

ABAP Development

entry.title: Re: Step-by-Step Guide: Extracting Pegging Data with the New SAP IBP API
entry.content: How is the performance with this extraction. Our use case is to provide visibility to our customer with the later status of the sales order. I understand snapshot is point in time data. Is the performance of extraction good enough to extract the data multiple times a day?
